passage: after 1 May 1993

On 16 September 1993 a new decision refusing to restore the two‑thirds of the property to the applicants was issued. The applicants appealed. On 17 June 1994 the City Mayor quashed that decision finding that the District Mayor should have been excluded from examining the issue as the District Office had been a party to the sale of that part of the property to third parties which was the subject matter of the case.

Between 1994 and 1996 the matter remained dormant. Following numerous interventions by the applicants and their complaints about the inactivity of the administration, the District Prosecutor intervened and filed a complaint with the Board of Appeal of the Local Government (Samorządowe Kolegium Odwoławcze). On 13 November 1996 the Board of Appeal found that this complaint was substantiated and it obliged the District Office to give a decision in the applicants' case before 15 December 1996.

In the meantime, on 23 October 1996 the District Office rendered a decision on the merits of the case. With reference to the previous decision finding that the District Office had not been competent to examine matters relating to transactions to which the given Office had been

Meanwhile, on 23 October 1996, the District Office made a final decision on the case, citing issues with the District Office's competence to handle transactions involving itself.

In so far as the applicant had complained about his continued preventive detention for a period exceeding ten years, his complaint was ill-founded. His continued preventive detention on the basis of Article 67d § 3 of the Criminal Code, as amended in 1998, was constitutional. The criminal courts had further respected the principle of proportionality in respect of deprivations of liberty in their decisions.
D. Subsequent developments

On 31 July 2009 the Freiburg Regional Court, reviewing the necessity of the applicant's continued detention, decided that the applicant was to remain in preventive detention as, owing to his criminal tendencies, he was still liable to commit serious offences resulting in considerable psychological or physical harm to the victims.

On 31 August 2009 the Karlsruhe Court of Appeal quashed that decision and remitted the case to the Freiburg Regional Court. It found that the Regional Court had not sufficiently established the facts on which it had based its decision and had failed to hear the medical expert, who had submitted a report in writing on its request, also in person at the hearing.
On 11 June 2010 the Federal Constitutional Court dismissed the applicant's request of 15 May 2010 that the

Regarding the time limit, the applicant's complaint regarding continued detention for over ten years was found to be unfounded. The continued preventive detention, based on Article 67d § 3 of the Criminal Code (as amended in 1998), was lawful. The criminal courts ensured the application of the principle of proportionality in their rulings concerning restrictions on freedom. 

In terms of subsequent developments, on an unspecified date, the court reassessed the necessity of the applicant's continued detention. They decided to uphold the preventive detention as the applicant, due to their criminal tendencies, posed a risk of committing serious offenses that could cause significant harm. On another unspecified date, the reviewing court overturned this decision, directing the case back to the original court, as the Regional Court did not adequately substantiate its decision and did not hear the medical expert who had provided a written report. On yet another unspecified date, the Federal Constitutional Court rejected the applicant's appeal on a specific request.

Judicial decisions adhered to the principle of proportionality regarding liberty constraints. In subsequent developments, the Freiburg Regional Court on July 31, 2009, decided that the applicant should continue to be detained because of his criminal inclinations, which posed a risk of serious offenses causing significant harm to victims. On August 31, 2009, the Karlsruhe Court of Appeal overturned this decision, directing the case back to the Regional Court for further fact-finding, particularly in light of the medical expert's report. On June 11, 2010, the Federal Constitutional Court declined to grant the applicant's appeal dated May 15, 2010, for a reevaluation.

The Polish Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr K. Drzewicki, of the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs.

On 19 November 2002 the Fourth Section decided to communicate the complaint concerning the length of the proceedings to the Government. Under the provisions of Article 29 § 3 of the Convention, it decided to examine the merits of the application at the same time as its admissibility.
THE FACTS
The applicant was born in 1924 and lives in Warsaw, Poland.

The case in question was an application (number 77759/01) brought before the European Court of Human Rights by Mrs Zofia Porembska, a Polish national, alleging issues related to the duration of proceedings against the Republic of Poland. The application was lodged under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms on 20 November 2000. Mr K. Drzewicki represented the Polish Government at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In July 1995, her brother instituted legal proceedings at the Warsaw District Court to secure a ruling declaring his mother’s heirs. The basis for this claim was a will allegedly made by their mother. In February 1996, Mrs Porembska contested the will. An originally scheduled hearing for April 4, 1996, was postponed due to her request.

public_paraphrase: The officer who fired the shots resulting in a fatality had their name withheld. On a certain unspecified date, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland issued a certificate to protect certain information from being disclosed at the inquest, deeming its disclosure to be against the public interest and potentially compromising ongoing intelligence operations. The Coroner's inquest began on another unspecified date, with the applicant and their family being represented by a solicitor and counsel. The opposing party's representatives also appeared. The Coroner heard evidence from multiple witnesses over three and a half days, including the applicant, soldiers, and a pathologist. These witnesses faced cross-examination. Sergeant A stated he would not testify before the Coroner. Around a specific unspecified date, the.Community for the Assembly (CAJ) submitted a statement to the Coroner from another civilian witness who was a black taxi driver present at the scene. On another specific date, the Coroner denied the request by the applicant's counsel to de-identify certain witnesses. The proceedings were subsequently adjourned, at the request of the applicant's family, to allow for further preparation.
private_paraphrase: On January 2, 1995, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland issued a certificate identifying certain information as critical to maintain the secrecy of RUC intelligence operations and thus should not be disclosed during the inquest. The inquest for Pearse Jordan commenced on January 4, 1995. Both the applicant and his family, along with legal representation, were present, as well as the RUC who sent their representatives. The inquest lasted three and a half days, hearing testimonies from 19 individuals, including the applicant, eight civilians, three soldiers, and seven police officers, plus a pathologist. Some witnesses were cross-examined. Sergeant A declined to appear before the Coroner. On January 8, 1995, the Committee for the Assurance of Justice (CAJ) submitted a statement about another civilian witness, a driver of a black taxi who had been present at the scene. On January 10, 1995, the Coroner declined the applicant's request to shield the identities of the RUC witnesses. The inquest subsequent to this decision was suspended on January 16, 1995, at the request of Pearse Jordan's family.

passage: in Bursa. The Turkish Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent.

On 12 June 2009 the President of the Second Section decided to give notice of the application to the Government. It was also decided to rule on the admissibility and merits of the application at the same time (Article 29 § 1).
THE FACTS
THE CIRCUMSTANCES OF THE CASE
The applicants were born in 1952, 1960, 1962 and 1934 respectively and live in Bursa.

In 2004 the General Directorate of Highways seized a plot of land belonging to the applicants without any formal expropriation, for the construction of a highway. The applicants brought an action before the Karacabey Civil Court to obtain compensation for the de facto expropriation of their property. They requested 5,500 Turkish liras (TRY) as compensation from the court and reserved their right to increase this claim in due course.

On 22 June 2006 the Karacabey Civil Court awarded the applicants TRY 5,500 as compensation for the de facto expropriation of their land, as requested, plus interest. The applicants initiated execution proceedings before the Bursa Execution Office to obtain that amount (file no. 2009/2802).
On 13 March 2007 the Court of Cassation upheld the judgment
